textline.text: Department of Sociology, University of Texas at Austin
305 East 23rd Street, A1700 ! Austin, TX 78712-0118
Phone: (512) 906-5698 ! E-mail: amina.zarrugh@utexas.edu
EDUCATION
Ph.D. 2016 (expected). Doctor of Philosophy in Sociology with Portfolio in Women’s &
Gender Studies. University of Texas at Austin.
Dissertation: “‘Only God Knows’: The Emergence of a Family Movement Against State
Violence in Libya” supervised by Mounira M. Charrad (chair), Ari Adut, Javier Auyero,
Sofian Merabet, and Michael P. Young
Comprehensive Exams: Passed with distinction in the area of political sociology (2012)
M.A. 2011. Master of Arts in Sociology. University of Texas at Austin.
B.A.
2008. Bachelor of Arts in Sociology (with Departmental Honors) and Government,
High Honors. University of Texas at Austin.
AREAS OF INTEREST
Culture, gender, global/transnational sociology, law and deviance, political sociology, race &
ethnicity, religion, social movements, violence, North Africa and the Middle East
PEER-REVIEW PUBLICATIONS
Zarrugh, Amina. Revise and resubmit at Qualitative Sociology. “‘Revolutionizing the Pulpit’:
Global Discourses of Terrorism and the Policing of Piety and Masculinity in Libya.”
Zarrugh, Amina. Revise and resubmit at Ethnic and Racial Studies. “The Politics of Dis-claiming
Whiteness: Arab American Racial Formation in a Post-9/11 Era”
Charrad, Mounira M. and Amina Zarrugh. 2014. “Equal or Complementary?: Women in the
New Tunisian Constitution After the Arab Spring.” The Journal of North African Studies
MANUSCRIPTS UNDER REVIEW & IN PREPARATION
Charrad, Mounira, Amina Zarrugh, & Hyun Jeong Ha. Under review at Social Problems. “‘You
Killed Our Brothers’: The ‘Reclamation’ Master Frame in the 2011 Arab Uprisings.”
Romero, Luis & Amina Zarrugh. Proposed to special issue of Ethnic and Racial Studies.
“‘Converged Racial Framing’: The Politics of Immigration and Terrorism”
FELLOWSHIPS AND GRANTS
Dissertation Diversity Fellowship, Ithaca College ($35,000; declined)
Endowed Continuing Fellowship, University of Texas at Austin ($38,000)
Graduate Research Fellowship, National Science Foundation
(Three years; total $121,500)
Rapoport Summer Graduate Fellow, The Bernard and Audre Rapoport Center for
Human Rights and Justice, School of Law, University of Texas at Austin
Graduate Student Professional Development Award (Travel), Department of
Sociology, University of Texas at Austin ($400-500 per annum)
Undergraduate Research Fellowship, University of Texas Co-op ($600)
Liberal Arts Honors Yearly (Senior) Scholarship, College of Liberal Arts,
University of Texas at Austin ($2000)
Liberal Arts Merit Scholarship, College of Liberal Arts, University of Texas at
Austin ($1500)
Mary Sue Collins Hibbs Scholarship, Department of Sociology, University of
Texas at Austin ($1000)
HONORS AND AWARDS
Intellectual Entrepreneurship Graduate Mentor Award, Division of Diversity and
Community Engagement (DDCE), University of Texas at Austin ($1000)
Honors Distinction, Comprehensive Exams in Political Sociology, University of
Texas at Austin
NON-PEER REVIEW PUBLICATIONS
Book Chapters
Zarrugh, Amina. Forthcoming. “Memories of Martyrs: Disappearance and Women’s Claims
Against State Violence in Libya” in Women Rising: Resistance, Revolution, Reform in the
Arab Spring and Beyond. Edited by R. Stephan and M.M. Charrad. New York: New York
University Press.
Charrad, Mounira M. and Amina Zarrugh. Forthcoming. “Constructing Citizenship: Gender
and Changing Discourses in Tunisia” in Gendered Citizenship: The Challenges of
Representation. Edited by H. Danielson, K. Jegerstedt, R. L. Muriaas, and B. Ytre-Arne.
Palgrave.
Charrad, Mounira M. and Amina Zarrugh. 2015. “Gender, Religion, and State in the Middle
East” in Emerging Trends in the Social and Behavioral Sciences: Interdisciplinary Directions.
Edited by R.A. Scott and S.M. Kosslyn. Hoboken: John Wiley and Sons.
Essays and News Articles
Charrad, Mounira M. and Amina Zarrugh. 2015. “Contradictions of the Tunisian state:
Women’s rights and gendered repression.” Baker Institute for Public Policy, Rice
University. Published by The Houston Chronicle blog. July 30, 2015.
Charrad, Mounira M. and Amina Zarrugh. 2013. “The Arab Spring and Women’s Rights in
Tunisia.” e-International Relations. September 4, 2013.
Zarrugh, Amina. 2012. “Discordant Voices: Libya consulate attack poses hard questions about
Arab Spring.” Op-ed, College of Liberal Arts, University of Texas. November 9.
Zarrugh, Amina. 2011. “Working Paper Series Generates Cross-Disciplinary Engagement”
Rapoport Center for Human Rights and Social Justice Annual Review 2010-2011: 13.
Book Reviews
Zarrugh, Amina. 2012. Review of K. Samman, The Clash of Modernities: The Islamist Challenge to
Jewish, Turkish, and Arab Nationalism (Boulder: Paradigm Publishers, 2010), darkmatter
General Issue 10.
Zarrugh, Amina. 2012. Review of Z. Salime, Between Feminism and Islam: Human Rights and
Sharia Law in Morocco (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2011), Mobilization
Zarrugh, Amina. 2012. Review of R.A. Caldwell, Fallgirls: Gender and the Framing of Torture at
Abu Ghraib (Burlington: Ashgate, 2012). Societies Without Borders 7 (2): 254-257.
Zarrugh, Amina. 2011. Review of A. Toscano, Fanaticism: On the Uses of an Idea (New York:
Verso, 2010), Sociological Insight 3: 175-177.
PRESENTATIONS
Zarrugh, Amina. “Challenging the Body Politic Along the Benghazi Corniche: The
Semiotics of Protest Among Families in Libya.” American Institute for Maghrib
Studies (AIMS) Dissertation Workshop. Department of Middle Eastern Studies,
University of California-Berkeley. October 10-11.
Romero, Luis and Amina Zarrugh. “‘Converged Racial Framing’: The Politics of
Immigration and Terrorism at the U.S.-Mexico Border.” “Islamophobia and
Surveillance: Genealogies of a Global Order” Symposium. Edge Hill University,
UK. September 25. [via Skype]
Zarrugh, Amina. “Family Movement Politics: Mobilizations Against State
Violence in Libya.” Panel for Session on Arab Americans, “Arab Refugees and
Political Participation.” American Sociological Association Annual Meeting,
Chicago, IL. August 22-25.
Zarrugh, Amina. “‘Only God Knows’: Missing Bodies and the Semiotics of Family
Movement Protests in Libya.” Panel of ASA Section on Body and Embodiment,
“The Body Politic: Law, Nationalism, and the State.” American Sociological
Association Annual Meeting, San Francisco, CA. August 16-19.
Zarrugh, Amina. “‘We Want Their Pictures’: Visuals as Expressions and Demands
During Protests in Libya.” The Public Image, International Visual Sociology
Association Annual Conference, Centre for Urban and Community Research,
Goldsmiths, University of London, England. July 8-10.
Zarrugh, Amina. “‘We Want to See as They Saw’: Mothers of Abu Salim and
Regime Violence in Libya.” New Directions in Anthropology, Rice University,
Houston, TX. March 22-23.
Zarrugh, Amina and Hyun Jeong Ha. “Protest as Performance: Group Solidarity
in Mobilizations in Tunisia, Egypt, and Libya.” Locating Solidarity: A Critical
Investigation of the Social World, The New School for Social Research, New
York, NY. March 31.
Zarrugh, Amina. “‘Revenge of the Virtuous Women’: Framing of Gender and
Violence by Palestinian Militant Organizations.” Making Connections:
Movements and Research in a Global Context, Collective Behavior and Social
Movements Section Workshop, University of Nevada, August 19 & American
Sociological Association Annual Meeting, Las Vegas, NV. August 20-23.
Zarrugh, Amina. “Strategic Framing: Organizations and the (Un)Problematic
Sponsorship of Female Suicide Bombers.” Strategic Decision-Making in Labor and
Social Movement Organizations: An Interdisciplinary Graduate Student
Conference, University of California at Los Angeles. May 28.
TEACHING
“Punishment and Society” (2015)
Assistant Instructor (Instructor of Record)
Teaching Assistant
“Life and Death Decisions” (2013); “Sociology of Health and Well-being” (2012);
“Population and Society” (2011 and 2012)
PEDAGOGY AND MENTORSHIP
Inclusive Classrooms Leadership Certificate, Division of Diversity and
Community Engagement, University of Texas at Austin
Teaching Certificate in First-Year Interdisciplinary Instruction, School of
Undergraduate Studies, University of Texas at Austin
Graduate Student Mentor, Intellectual Entrepreneurship Program, College of
Communication
PROFESSIONAL SERVICE
Reviewer for International Journal of Violence and Conflict; Journal of Women, Politics,
& Policy; Sociological Focus; Sociological Insight
2012-2015 Power, History, and Society (PHS) Graduate Student-Faculty Network,
Department of Sociology, University of Texas at Austin
• Graduate Student Coordinator; “Middle East Working Group” Organizer
Rapoport Center Human Rights Working Paper Series, The Bernard and Audre
Rapoport Center for Human Rights and Justice
• Head of the Editorial Committee (2011-2012)
• Co-Head of the Editorial Committee and Webmaster (2010-2011)
• Editor for English Translations, Sur: International Journal on Human Rights,
São Paulo, Brazil
Copy Editor, Intersections: Women’s and Gender Studies in Review across Disciplines,
University of Texas graduate student publication
PUBLIC SOCIOLOGY
Zarrugh, Amina. 2014. “Review: Anthony Shadid’s House of Stone.” The Smithville
Times. March 10, 2014.
Zarrugh, Amina. 2013. “Review: Hisham Matar’s In the Country of Men.” The
Smithville Times. September 12, 2013.
Keynote Speaker, Smithville Community Discussion on Hisham Matar’s In the
Country of Men. “Let’s Talk About it: Muslim Journeys – Points of View” Series.
Smithville High School. Smithville, TX. September 16, 2013. See news about
community and library responses.
Consultant Scholar, Bridging Cultures Program (Series on “Muslim Journeys”).
Smithville, TX. Funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities in
collaboration with the American Library Association.
Panelist, “Why Should Women Do Research?” INSPIRE Leadership Program:
Empowering Texas Women Leaders, Center for Women’s and Gender Studies,
University of Texas at Austin. October 6, 2011.
LANGUAGES
• English (reading, writing, speaking)
• Arabic (intermediate reading, writing, and North African dialects speaking)
• French (intermediate reading, writing and speaking)
• American Institute for Maghrib Studies
PROFESSIONAL MEMBERSHIPS
• American Sociological Association
• Middle East Studies Association
REFERENCES
Sofian Merabet
Assistant Professor
Department of Anthropology
University of Texas at Austin
2201 Speedway Stop C3200, Austin, TX 78712
sofian.merabet@austin.utexas.edu
